The Difference between Two Beta Distributions

Source: R/betadiff.R
betadiff.Rd

Density, distribution function and quantile function for the distribution of the difference of two beta distributions with parameters parX and parY

Usage

dbetadiff(z, parY, parX)

pbetadiff(q, parY, parX)

qbetadiff(p, parY, parX)

Arguments

z

vector of differences

parY

two parameters of Y's beta distribution (Treatment)

parX

two parameters of X's beta distribution (Control)

q

vector of quantiles

p

vector of probabilities

Value

dbetadiff gives the density, pbetadiff the distribution function, qbetadiff the quantile function.

Examples

## Plot pdf of the betadiff distribution
parX <- c(1, 52)
parY <- c(5.5, 20.5)

z <- seq(from = -1, to = 1, length = 100)
plot(z, dbetadiff(z, parY = parY, parX = parX),
  type = "l"
)


## calculate probability

## for Go:
test <- integrate(
  f = dbetadiff,
  parY = parY,
  parX = parX,
  lower = 0.15,
  upper = 1
)
str(test)
#> List of 5
#>  $ value       : num 0.677
#>  $ abs.error   : num 2.41e-07
#>  $ subdivisions: int 1
#>  $ message     : chr "OK"
#>  $ call        : language integrate(f = dbetadiff, lower = 0.15, upper = 1, parY = parY, parX = parX)
#>  - attr(*, "class")= chr "integrate"
test$value
#> [1] 0.677447

## vary close to the Monte Carlo result:
mean(rbeta(n = 1e6, parY[1], parY[2]) -
  rbeta(n = 1e6, parX[1], parX[2]) > 0.15)
#> [1] 0.677582


## similar case for Stop:
integrate(
  f = dbetadiff,
  parY = parY,
  parX = parX,
  lower = -1,
  upper = 0.5
)
#> 0.9993974 with absolute error < 8.6e-06

mean(rbeta(n = 1e6, parY[1], parY[2]) -
  rbeta(n = 1e6, parX[1], parX[2]) < 0.5)
#> [1] 0.999387

test <- qbetadiff(
  p = 0.2,
  parY = parY,
  parX = parX
)
pbetadiff(
  q = test,
  parY = parY,
  parX = parX
)
#> [1] 0.200003
